metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: DSA Quicksort with Python
Quicksort
As the name suggests, Quicksort is one of the fastest sorting algorithms.
content.html: As the name suggests, Quicksort is one of the fastest sorting algorithms.

content.text: The Quicksort algorithm takes an array of values, chooses one of the values as the 'pivot' element, and moves the other values so that lower values are on the left of the pivot element, and higher values are on the right of it.
content.html: The Quicksort algorithm takes an array of values, chooses one of the values as the 'pivot' element, and moves the other values so that lower values are on the left of the pivot element, and higher values are on the right of it.

content.text: In this tutorial the last element of the array is chosen to be the pivot element, but we could also have chosen the first element of the array, or any element in the array really.
content.html: In this tutorial the last element of the array is chosen to be the pivot element, but we could also have chosen the first element of the array, or any element in the array really.

content.text: Then, the Quicksort algorithm does the same operation recursively on the sub-arrays to the left and right side of the pivot element. This continues until the array is sorted.
content.html: Then, the Quicksort algorithm does the same operation recursively on the sub-arrays to the left and right side of the pivot element. This continues until the array is sorted.

content.text: Recursion is when a function calls itself.
content.html: Recursion is when a function calls itself.

content.text: After the Quicksort algorithm has put the pivot element in between a sub-array with lower values on the left side, and a sub-array with higher values on the right side, the algorithm calls itself twice, so that Quicksort runs again for the sub-array on the left side, and for the sub-array on the right side. The Quicksort algorithm continues to call itself until the sub-arrays are too small to be sorted.
content.html: After the Quicksort algorithm has put the pivot element in between a sub-array with lower values on the left side, and a sub-array with higher values on the right side, the algorithm calls itself twice, so that Quicksort runs again for the sub-array on the left side, and for the sub-array on the right side. The Quicksort algorithm continues to call itself until the sub-arrays are too small to be sorted.

content.text: The algorithm can be described like this:
content.html: The algorithm can be described like this:

content.text: How it works:
content.html: How it works:

content.text: Manual Run Through
Before we implement the Quicksort algorithm in a programming language, let's manually run through a short array, just to get the idea.
content.html: Before we implement the Quicksort algorithm in a programming language, let's manually run through a short array, just to get the idea.

content.text: Step 1: We start with an unsorted array.
content.html: Step 1: We start with an unsorted array.

content.text: Step 2: We choose the last value 3 as the pivot element.
content.html: Step 2: We choose the last value 3 as the pivot element.

content.text: Step 3: The rest of the values in the array are all greater than 3, and must be on the right side of 3. Swap 3 with 11.
content.html: Step 3: The rest of the values in the array are all greater than 3, and must be on the right side of 3. Swap 3 with 11.

content.code_html: [ 3, 9, 12, 7, 11]

content.text: Step 4: Value 3 is now in the correct position. We need to sort the values to the right of 3. We choose the last value 11 as the new pivot element.
content.html: Step 4: Value 3 is now in the correct position. We need to sort the values to the right of 3. We choose the last value 11 as the new pivot element.

content.text: Step 5: The value 7 must be to the left of pivot value 11, and 12 must be to the right of it. Move 7 and 12.
content.html: Step 5: The value 7 must be to the left of pivot value 11, and 12 must be to the right of it. Move 7 and 12.

content.text: Step 6: Swap 11 with 12 so that lower values 9 and 7 are on the left side of 11, and 12 is on the right side.
content.html: Step 6: Swap 11 with 12 so that lower values 9 and 7 are on the left side of 11, and 12 is on the right side.

content.text: Step 7: 11 and 12 are in the correct positions. We choose 7 as the pivot element in sub-array [ 9, 7], to the left of 11.
content.html: Step 7: 11 and 12 are in the correct positions. We choose 7 as the pivot element in sub-array [ 9, 7], to the left of 11.

content.text: Step 8: We must swap 9 with 7.
content.html: Step 8: We must swap 9 with 7.

content.text: And now, the array is sorted.
content.html: And now, the array is sorted.

content.html: Run the simulation below to see the steps above animated:

content.text: Implement Quicksort in Python

To write a 'quickSort' method that splits the array into shorter and shorter sub-arrays we use recursion. This means that the 'quickSort' method must call itself with the new sub-arrays to the left and right of the pivot element. Read more about recursion here .
content.html: To write a 'quickSort' method that splits the array into shorter and shorter sub-arrays we use recursion. This means that the 'quickSort' method must call itself with the new sub-arrays to the left and right of the pivot element. Read more about recursion here.

content.text: To implement the Quicksort algorithm in a Python program, we need:
content.html: To implement the Quicksort algorithm in a Python program, we need:

content.text: The resulting code looks like this:
content.html: The resulting code looks like this:

content.code_html:
def partition(array, low, high):
  pivot = array[high]
  i = low - 1

  for j in range(low, high):
     if array[j] <= pivot:
       i += 1
       array[i], array[j] = array[j], array[i]

  array[i+1], array[high] = array[high], array[i+1]
  return i+1

def quicksort(array, low=0, high=None):
  if high is None:
    high = len(array) - 1

  if low < high:
    pivot_index = partition(array, low, high)
    quicksort(array, low, pivot_index-1)
    quicksort(array, pivot_index+1, high)

mylist = [64, 34, 25, 5, 22, 11, 90, 12]
quicksort(mylist)
print(mylist)

content.text: Quicksort Time Complexity

The worst case scenario for Quicksort is O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 ) . This is when the pivot element is either the highest or lowest value in every sub-array, which leads to a lot of recursive calls. With our implementation above, this happens when the array is already sorted.
content.html: The worst case scenario for Quicksort is O(n2)O(n2). This is when the pivot element is either the highest or lowest value in every sub-array, which leads to a lot of recursive calls. With our implementation above, this happens when the array is already sorted.

content.text: But on average, the time complexity for Quicksort is actually just O ( n log n ) O ( n log ⁡ n ) , which is a lot better than for the previous sorting algorithms we have looked at. That is why Quicksort is so popular.
content.html: But on average, the time complexity for Quicksort is actually just O(nlogn)O(nlog⁡n), which is a lot better than for the previous sorting algorithms we have looked at. That is why Quicksort is so popular.

content.text: Below you can see the significant improvement in time complexity for Quicksort in an average scenario O ( n log n ) O ( n log ⁡ n ) , compared to the previous sorting algorithms Bubble, Selection and Insertion Sort with time complexity O ( n 2 ) O ( n 2 ) :
content.html: Below you can see the significant improvement in time complexity for Quicksort in an average scenario O(nlogn)O(nlog⁡n), compared to the previous sorting algorithms Bubble, Selection and Insertion Sort with time complexity O(n2)O(n2):

content.text: The recursion part of the Quicksort algorithm is actually a reason why the average sorting scenario is so fast, because for good picks of the pivot element, the array will be split in half somewhat evenly each time the algorithm calls itself. So the number of recursive calls do not double, even if the number of values n n double.
content.html: The recursion part of the Quicksort algorithm is actually a reason why the average sorting scenario is so fast, because for good picks of the pivot element, the array will be split in half somewhat evenly each time the algorithm calls itself. So the number of recursive calls do not double, even if the number of values nn double.
